rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Proliferation and renewal of spermatogonia following x-irradiation of the rat testis
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The behaviour of the two classes of spermatogonial stem cells (AO and A1-A4) was investigated following 300r of X-rays to rat testes. Radioautographs of cross sections and whole mounts of seminiferous tubules were prepared from animals injected with 3H-thymidine. In nonirradiated controls type AO spermatogonia were generally dormant, while type A1 spermatogonia periodically initiated a series of divisions resulting in the production of spermatocytes and new type A1 spermatogonia. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Anatomy

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Metabolism of low density lipoproteins in the rat
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The secretion of the lipid and protein components of low density plasma lipoproteins (d < 1.063) by perfused rat liver have been studied simultaneously using palmitate-9, 10-3 H and leucine-l-l4c as precursors. The labelled lipid moiety appears in the circulation after a shorter lag period than the protein indicating that the two components are not synthesized simultaneously. Puromycin inhibits the release of labelled lipoprotein following a delay which is due to exhaustion of an intracellular pool of apolipoprotein. More labelled lipoprotein lipid is released by the perfused liver when whole blood is used as the perfusate than when an albumin-Ringer preparation is used although there is no additional glyceride release. This indicates that there is an exchange of lipid between liver and plasma lipoprotein. This exchange has also been demonstrated by following uptake of doubly labelled lipoprotein by the perfused liver. The lipid component disappears more rapidly from the perfusate than the protein. Lipoprotein triglyceride is removed intact by the perfused liver in a three-stage process, initial trapping of the entire lipoprotein molecule, exchange, and uptake. The lipid fatty acid is incorporated primarily into liver phospholipid. The exchange has also been demonstrated in vivo where it appears more rapid indicating the participation of other tissues.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Elastic surface wave propagation in anisotropic crystals
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A general numerical method has been developed for the determination of the propagation characteristics of elastic surfaces waves on anisotropic crystals. Extensive studies have revealed that these waves can be propagated in any direction on ail planes of anisotropic crystals. Near certain directions, in which the normal surface wave degenerates continuously into the transverse bulk wave, the penetration of the surface wave into the solid is deep. However, near these special directions, pseudosurface waves that can be propagated for a wide range of directions are found, and their form is explained. The effect of water loading on the propagation of both normal and pseudo-surface waves is also investigated. A gradient Method of finding the power-flow directions for normal surface waves has been developed. The results are compared with the more standard Poyntingvector method. The calculation of power-flow directions for pseudo-surfaces waves is also illustrated.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Electrical Engineering

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The metabolism of pregnenolone in normal subjects and hypertensive individuals
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: We have adapted the double isotope derivative assay technique for the measurement of the excretion rate of delta-5-pregnenediol, and applied this method for a comparative study of the metabolism of pregnenolone in normal subjects and hypertensive individuals. When the excretion of delta-5-pregnenediol glucuronide and sulfate by normal and hypertensive individuals was compared, no significant differences were observed. From the urine of normal and hypertensive subjects given pregnenolone-7-alpha-3H intravenously, we have isolated labeled delta-5-pregnenediol glucuronide and delta-5-pregnenediol sulfate, and determined their specific activity. No significant difference existed between the specific activities of the urinary delta-5-pregnenediol glucuronides as estimated in both groups of subjects. However, when the specific activities of urinary delta-5-pregnenediol sulfates were compared, it could be seen that the specific activity was significantly higher in hypertensive subjects. This points to a defect in the metabolism of pregnenolone in such patients.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Investigative Medicine

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Interpretation of gravity data due to faults and dikes
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Formulas are given for the gravity anomalies of several types of two-dimensional faults and dikes, such as a single fault cutting a series of beds, several parallel faults cutting a bed or a dike inclined at an arbitrary angle to the vertical. Methods of interpretation of the gravity anomalies of a two dimensional structures based upon the first and the second horizontal derivative of gravity are discussed. Expressions are obtained showing the relationships between the parameters of the various two-dimensional structures and the position and amplitude of the second, derivative maximum and minimum. The Fourier transform formulas for the gravity anomalies of the two-dimensional structures are derived. For small values of omega, the Fourier transforms give valuable information about the parameters of the structures. Under favorable conditions the amplitude spectrum of the Fourier transforms can give information about the depth as well as the inclination of the anomalous mass. The validity of the new formulas and the suitability cf the new interpretation techniques are tested by comparing results obtained from field measurements with the known geology of the structures.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mining Engineering

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Induction of cytochrome C in yeast
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: An accurate method of assay of the cytochrome c of yeast has been developed. Actinomycin D affects with difficulty RNA synthesis and cytochrome c induction under the influence of oxygen in a brewer's strain of the yeast S. cerevisiae. Proflavine is completely and immediately effective in inhibiting RNA synthesis in these cells. The rapidly labelled RNA fraction decays to acid-soluble nucleotides at two different rates. Alpha-amino levulinic acid synthetase activity in these cells is reduced dramatically in the presence of oxygen. This effect of oxygen is not due to a repression of synthesis of the enzyme but appears to be dependent in some way on protein synthesis. Results indicate that oxygen-induced cytochrome c synthesis in these yeast cells involves de nova protein synthesis and is dependent on newly formed RNA of a limited lifetime; the induced synthesis, however, is not dependent on an increased formation of precursors of the prosthetic group.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Dissociative electron attachment in the halogens
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A trapped electron apparatus employing an R.P.D. electron gun has been built for electron impact studies of excitation and negative ion formation. It operates in the energy range from 0 to 25 eV with a resolution of 0.35 eV and a reproducibility of ± 0.17 eV. Preliminary studies of hydrogen indicate reproducible structure in the dissociative attachment process known to occur between 8 and 10.7 eV. Four resonances attributed to dissociative attachment in chlorine have been identified with peak values at 0, 1.75, 3.07 and 5.9 ± 0.17 eV. The first three resonances have the same dissociation limit, while the fourth is distinct and contains reproducible structure. At higher energies, an excitation process and ion pair formation have been identified. Similar dissociative attachment processes in bromine give rise to resonance peaks at 0.05, 0.98 and 3.30 ± 0.17 eV. AIl of the processes lead to the same dissociation products. For iodine, dissociative attachment peaks arise at energies of 0.28, 0.58 and 2.15 ± 0.17 eV. AIl three processes produce products in the same energy states. A sharp break at 8.27 ± 0.17 eV is attributed to the initiation of ion pair formation.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Auditory discrimination of coded speech by deaf children
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Four studies constitute this series of experiments in which profoundly deaf children were trained to discriminate linearly amplified speech and speech coded by three different processes. The purpose of the experiments was to determine whether subjects could acquire better speech discrimination skills with frequency transposed (Coded) speech than with conventional linear amplification. In none of the four studies were discrimination scores for coded speech significantly different from scores for linearly amplified speech. In the final experiment, coded speech to the right ear and linearly amplified speech to the left did not lead to better results than either form of amplification presented binaurally.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Human Communication Disorders

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Study on the synthesis of samandarine
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Several lactams were prepared from testosterone and the stereochemistry of the dihydroderivatives was studied. It was found that hydrogenation of the alpha-beta-unsaturated lactams did not favour the A/B cis-isomer. A simple general route for converting 17-oxo-steroids into 16-oxo-steroids was worked out. A method of preparing 2-oximino-5-beta-steroid was investigated. This permitted an important intermediate, 17-beta-acetoxy-2-oximino-5-beta-androstan-3-ol, to be made. It cou1d be cleaved se1ectively to a cyano aldehyde derivative having proper stereochemistry and functionalities. However, introduction of a functional group at C-1 was not successful.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies on the mechanism of cortisone-induced acid secretion in guinea-pigs
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Guinea-pigs were found to be resistant not only to cortisone induced gastric ulceration, but to a variety of ulcerogenic stimuli. Extracts made from the guinea-pig stomach, given intraduodenally at the time of ligation had a protective effect upon gastric ulceration in the Shay rat. The cortisone-induced acid hypersecretion observed in guinea pigs could be increased following a) enhancement of histamine synthesis and b) inhibition of the oxidative deamination of histamine. It could be decreased following a) suppression of histamine synthesis and b) enhancement of the oxidative deamination of histamine. A histamine metabolite, alpha-N, N-dimethylhistamine, hitherto not found in mammalian tissue was detected in the stomachs of cortisone treated guinea-pigs. It has been suggested that cortisone might increase the formation of this metabolite which may be involved in the acid secretory response to cortisone.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Pharmacology and Therapeutics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Mechanisms of anaesthesia and some observations on synaptic inhibition
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: An experimenta1 preparation was developed in decerebrated cats for the study of synaptic transmission through the cuneate nucleus. Anaesthetics, and other relevant substances, were given by microiontophoresis, by superfusion of the nucleus, or by systemic administration. Procaine readily depressed the excitability of all cuneate cells, as well as the excitability of presynaptic nerve fibres. Sodium pentobarbitone (Nembutal) preferentially depressed the post-synaptic excitation of all types of cells, but higher doses were required to block conduction in nerve fibres. Halothane had no direct effect on the post-synaptic e1ements, or on the nerve fibres. However, it depressed the synaptic excitation of cuneothalamic units (but not that of "interneurones"). It also potentiated synaptic inhibition, as well as the depressant effects of GABA and glycine. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physiology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Cationic fluxes and some aspects of brain metabolism in vitro
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Evidence for the existence of active transport of phosphate in isolated rat brain has been presented. The rates of phosphate and glycine active transport have been studied in unstimulated, potassium and electrically stimulated brain slices. Stimulation of respiration of brain slices by a high concentration of K+ and by the application of electrical pulses appears to be dependent on the activity of the "sodium pump". The levels of tissue Na+ and K+ regulate the rate of acetate oxidation in brain slices. Studies of the rates of L-C14-acetate oxidation to C14O2 may be used to investigate fluxes of Na+ and K+ into the brain cell. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Isolation of biologically active substances from crown-gall tumor of tomato
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The work presented in this thesis describes methods by which biologically active substances could be isolated from extracts of crown-gall infected tomato stalks. Two active principles: tomatine and gomatine were isolated. Tomatine isolated from crown-gall infected tomato stalk extract was found to inhibit contractions of the isolated guinea-pig ileum preparation induced by: histamine, acetylcholine, bradykinin and barium chloride. Gomatine when assayed in vivo in guinea-pigs exerted significant protection against the effect of a lethal histamine aerosol. Gomatine also protected guinea-pigs actively sensitized to egg albumin against anaphylactic shock. When assayed in vitro, gomatine inhibited the contractions induced by histamine, bradykinin, acetylcholine, 5-HT, and SRS-A. Some chemical properties (including melting point, infrared spectrum and elementary analysis) of gomatine were determined.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Medicine

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Isolation and characterization of a protein allergen from short ragweed pollen
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: An allergenically active protein, Antigen Ra.3, was isolated from the aqueous extract of short ragweed pollen by the combined techniques of ammonium sulphate precipitation, gel filtration am ion exchange chromatography. Antigen Ra.3 was shown to be homogeneous by TEAE-cellulose chromatography, polyacrylamide disc electrophoresis, sedimentation velocity ultracentrifugation, gel filtration and immunodiffusion tests. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Medicine

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Steroid metabolism in various preparations of the rat adrenal
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Steroid hydroxylase activities detected in the rat adrenal preincubation medium (PIM) were located exclusively in the subcellular particulates. The characteristic accumulation of 11-beta-hydroxyprogesterone when 14-C-progesterone was incubated at 37ºC with the PIN obtained from incubations at 37ºC could be reproduced with a dilute homogenate of rat adrenals (2.4 mg/4 ml), and was related to a higher susceptibility of 21-hydroxylase to denaturation, relative to that of ll-beta-hydroxylase. This last conclusion was reached from the observations that: (a) Preincubation of tissue et 0ºC - rather than at 37ºC - followed by incubation of the media at 37ºC led to an increased formation of 14-C-corticosterone from 14-C-progesterone, concomitant with a lesser accumulation of ll-beta-hydroxyprogesterone. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Investigative Medicine

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The immune response by lymphoid cells in vitro
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Bone marrow cells obtained from normal unimmunized rabbits were stimulated to undergo blastogenesis and mitosis and to incorporate tritiated thymidine upon incubation with various protein antigens in vitro. Call suspensions of other lymphoid organs, obtained from normal rabbits, failed to respond in this fashion. This in vitro response did not occur with bone marrow cells of immunized rabbits, although it was observed with lymph node and spleen cells obtained from previously immunized rabbits. The immune nature of the bone marrow blastogenic response was demonstrated by the detection of specific antibody, by the fluorescent antibody technique, within the stimulated cells. The response of the bone marrow cells was localized to the lymphocyte-enriched cell fraction following centrifugation of the whole bone marrow in a linear sucrose density gradient. The findings suggest that the bane marrow lymphocyte plays an important role during the induction of a primary immune response.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Medicine

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The juxtaglomerular complex in various experimental states: light and electron microscopic studies
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Modifications of Helly's and of Stieve's fixatives, and of Bowie stain demonstrate with excellent results the components of the JG complex. A marked activating effect results by the combined addition of BaCI and CoCl2 for the histochemical demonstration of the hexosemonophosphate2 shunt enzymes. A semi-quantitative index was derived for assessing the activity of these enzymes in the macula densa (MDL), with parallel measurements of the juxta-glomerular cell granularity (JGI) and renin. Complete aortic ligature between the two renal arteries in rats over 300 g consistently produced atrophic left kidneys accompanied by hypertension. JGI and MDI studies on sex and various strains of rats did not reflect significant differences. However, a zonal distribution of these two parameters was observed. In dogs and beavers, a similar distribution of the JGI was also encountered.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Investigative Medicine

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Active transport and related metabolism in in vitro preparations of guinea pig small intestine
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This thesis deals with certain aspects of active transport and related metabolism in in vitro preparations of guinea pig small intestine. Incubation of averted sacs of small intestine in medium containing EDTA (2mM) results in separation of the mucosal epithelial cells from the underlying tissue and subsequently from each other. Cells isolated by this procedure appear morphologically intact, respire actively for more than 60 minutes and retain the capacity to oxidize added substrate for this duration. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Excretion of uric acid in man and the dog
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A permanent aciduria and a significant decrement in urinary excretion of ammonia are reported in gouty patients, free of gross renal dysfunction, during the administration of a high purine diet. A decrement in urinary excretion of uric acid without rise in plasma urate concentration is also evident in these patients. Hyperuricemia per se does not appear to influence the mechanisms of urine acidification, since the induction of an acute hyperuricemia fails to modify urinary pH, renal excretion of titra table acid and ammonia in the mongrel dog. Experiments performed in both mongrel and dalmatian dogs reveal that ammonia is the main adaptive mechanism for hydrogen excretion during either acute or chronic metabolic acidosis. Furthermore, the increment in urinary ammonia occurs rapidly and is not influenced by prolonged sodium restriction. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Investigated Medicine

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Distribution of cell web-containing reticular cells in the thymus and spleen of the rat
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: "Cell-web" - containing reticular cells selectively stained by the tannic acid-phosphomolybdic acid-amido black (TPA) technique were identified and their distribution analyzed in the thymus and spleen. In the cortex of the thymus, these cells formed a continuous layer on the inner surface of the capsule and around vessels, and constituted a loose network over the remaining of the cortex. In the medulla, two zones were distinguished: the "outer medulla" in which cell web-containing reticular cells were abundant and formed a dense network and the "inner medulla" in which no such cells were found. In the spleen, cell web-containing reticular cells were abundant in the periarterial lymphatic sheaths and formed a distinct layer separating the white pulp from the marginal zone. They also formed a delicate layer separating the germinal center from the cortex of lymphatic nodules. Thus, the thymus and spleen appeared to be compartmentalized by sheaths of TPA-stained reticular cells.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Anatomy

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The influence of the limbic system upon single neurons in the tuberal and lateral hypothalamus
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The effects of electrical stimulation in the amygdala, septum, midbrain tegmentum and hippocampus upon extracellularly recorded unit and slow potentials in the tuberal and lateral hypothalamic regions were studied in cats. The results of these experiments provide a quantitative assessment of the convergence of limbic input to the tuberal and lateral hypothalamus, establish the ventromedial nucleus as a focal object of limbic influence, and identify two functionally distinct amygdaloid efferent pathways which reach identical neurons within the ventromedial nucleus. In addition the extreme sensitivity of the hypothalamic. response to variations in the frequency of impulses arriving from the amygdala is shown. Finally, the presence of inhibitory interneurons within and near the lateral border of the ventromedial nucleus is demonstrated using physiological criteria, and morphological identification of these interneurons is tentatively provided.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Neurology and Neurosurgery

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The role of iodine deficiency and radiations in the production of thyroid tumors in the rat
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Tumors of the follicular cells of rat thyroid glands were produced with the intent of exploring the respective roles of radiations and hyperplasia. Such tumors, which can be malignant, were induced by x-irradiation, radioactivity, or prolonged low-iodine diet, alone or in combination. Thyroid glands were examined in serial sections; and, quantitative data were obtained on the incidence of tumor-bearing animals, the number of tumors per gland, and the total volume of tumors per gland. Hyperplasia, associated with low-iodine diet, induced in six to twelve months a greater yield of tumors than did radiations in the doses employed. However, when radiation was followed by hyperplasia, the yield was much more than expected by a simple additive effect of these two factors. The interpretation is that in carcinogenesis of the thyroid, radiation acts as an 'initiating' agent, whereas hyperplasia acts as a promoting agent (possibly also as an 'initiating' agent).
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Anatomy

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Further studies on the distribution and mechanism of action of a tissue antihistamine principle
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The distribution of antihistamine activity in extracts prepared from tissues of rat, guinea pig and dog has been investigated. It was observed that in some tissues (e.g. ear skin), the antihistamine activity paralleled the known histamine content; in other tissues (e.g. stomach), this was not so. The influence of pretreatment with Compound 48/80, semicarbazide along with a pyridoxine-deficient diet; reserpine, adrenalectomy, cortisone, diphenylhydantoin and/or phenobarbital upon the tissue antihistamine levels was also studied in the rat, guinea pig and doge Decreases in tissue histamine-inhibitory activity were observed in rats after Compound 48/80 (e.g. abdominal skin), semicarbazide and a pyridoxine-free diet (e.g. brain), or reserpine (e.g. lung). After adrenalectomy, decreases (e.g. kidney) or increases (e.g. stomach) in antihistamine activity were observed. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Pharmacology and Therapeutics

rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Department of Civil Engineering and Applied Mechanics
rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Dispersion of pollutants in wide and shallow rivers
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The chemical pollution survey of the Richelieu River, P. Q., has shown that under the present hydrologie regime of. the River and the volume and characteristics of wastes discharged into it, the degree of pollution is generally low. The only chemical pollutants which at times causes difficulties in water treatment plants are phenolic compounds, while A.B.S. and acid industrial wastes cause a localized pollution only. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Civil Engineering and Applied Mechanics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The metabolism of copper in the liver of the rat
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The intracellular distribution of hepatic copper has been studied in various physiological states. Normally hair the copper is recovered in the supernatant fraction; the remainder, in the nuclear, mitochondrial and microsomal fractions, in decreasing order. In copper-deficient rats mitochondria and cytoplasm suffer the greatest losses; in newborn, iron deficient and copper-injected rats, all of which have high concentrations of copper in the liver, mitochondria and nuclei have most of the excess copper. Studies of copper deposition have revealed a rapid uptake of the metal by the liver: after a single injection of ionic copper, mitochondrial, nuclear and cytoplasmic copper increase, reach a peak and decrease concurrently. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Psychiatry
